I observe those dharmas. Who cultivates bodhi? Who attains bodhi? Who wishes to attain it?
In the past, present, and future, who has realized it?
Is it attained by the body or by the mind?
If it is attained by the body, this body is without knowledge, just like grass, trees, sand, gravel, and walls, without any awareness.
The four great elements come together, born from one's parents, always requiring food, clothing, bathing, and massage, and will eventually decay and perish, this is the dharma of destruction.

This enlightenment is merely a name, without any real characteristics. It has no sound, no form, no accomplishment, no perception, no entry, no cognition, no going, and no coming. Such dharmas are also unfettered.

It surpasses all dharmas, transcending the three realms. It is unseen, unheard, without self or possessions, without an agent, without a location, without a dwelling, without grasping, without attachment, without emergence, without entry, without wishes, without abiding, without characteristics, without appearance, without there, without here, and cannot be shown, just like an illusion.

One who knows this is said to be enlightened.
If it is attained by the mind, this mind is undetermined, like an illusion, all arising from past deluded thoughts and karma, formless, ungraspable, like empty space.
Enlightenment has no location, is neither past, future, nor present, and all dharmas are empty.

Although there is verbal expression, it has a name but no reality. This is the unconditioned dharma, empty, without characteristics, without action, neither existent nor nonexistent, cannot be demonstrated, is inexpressible, and cannot be heard.

Bodhi is not attained in the past, not attained in the future, not attained in the present, and also not attained apart from the three times. It is signless, not created, and not non-created. If one can thus understand the dharmas of the three times, that is bodhi.
